pretext: Japanese can be a little intimidating to learn, especially with all the different characters. Don’t worry! We’ll take it slow, starting with hiragana. Let us first learn the vowels in hiragana. “a,” “i,” “u,” “e,” and “o”.

prompt: “a” is “あ.” An easy way to remember this would be to think of the character as an apple with a stem.
Next is “i.” “i” is represented by “い.” You can think of it as the shape of a melting Ice cube.
Our next vowel is “u.” “u” is represented by “う.” This one should be easy to remember as the character already looks like the letter “u” on its side.
Our next vowel is “e.” “e” is represented by the character “え.” Its sharp edge looks like an Elf’s ear.
Our last vowel is “o.” This is drawn as “お,” which is very similar to the hiragana character “a” (あ). However, instead of an apple, you can think of it as an Orange with a stem and a leaf.
